text: Embarking on a difficult journey always requires an incredible drive.
And nothing is more powerful than pain and the desire to prove everyone wrong, at a time when everyone doubts you.
And when we started Yes Theory, that's exactly what we all went through.
For a while some of us heavily struggled with mental health issues, but our friendship, and our work together, became our cure.
We believe that to truly become great, you have to go through a period in your life that almost seems impossible to overcome.
So if you'd allow me,
I'd like to tell you what that period was for each of us.
Amar left his home in Egypt at 15.
and ever since, he's been dealing with huge cultural disparities between the way he was brought up
and the way he's decided to live his life on his own terms.
He struggled with multiple episodes of depression over the past five years,
but somehow he always found a way to keep fighting to continue chasing his dreams.
Matt, on the other hand, struggled with severe anxiety,
which eventually built up to an ego death.
He stopped being the partying college student he was
to completely redefine himself into a hard-working, disciplined, and ambitious man.
Derin was living with a constant fear of never finishing anything.
A fear that he wasn't good at what he loved and would only ever go halfway.
As for me, my first company failed after three years,
just as the girl I had fallen in love with broke up with me.
And on top of it all, I developed chronic muscle injuries, forcing me to give up all my hobbies.
We were all seeking a new way of living and were in desperate need of a sense of direction.
Something that would help us heal and redefine ourselves.
Until one day...
against all odds, we found each other. Even though we were complete strangers at the time, we bonded over a simple idea.
The idea that routine is the enemy of time,
that counter-intuitively, in order to regain our sense of direction, we had to do something radically different.
So we all bailed on the plans we had that summer, and we decided to chase the unknown together.
It was chaos every day.
But we finally found the sense of direction that we had all been craving.
What we never expected was that it wasn't just the individual adventures that would change our lives.
But, in fact, our new-born friendship, and the overall journey that we went on together.
As strangers, the journey started off personal.
But quickly we became even more excited to see each other overcome our fears,
challenge ourselves, and redefine who we are together.
And behind the scenes,
We started to deal with our pains.
Pulling them from the depth of who we are, and into the light.
During that healing process, we discovered something incredible.
We discovered, what we call now...
The "Yes Theory."
We realized that the one word that united us and kept us going, was that simple "yes."
So, we made it our life mission to spread this lifestyle to as many young people as we possibly can.
And not to paint an unrealistic picture of life when you decide to take an alternative path,
I have to warn you. It requires a sh*t ton of sacrifices.
And in our story, there was a lot of those involved.
Amar  dropped out of a full-ride scholarship and turn down a $100,000 investment for a start-up.
Matt shut down his profitable street-wear clothing company, quit his job, and put his savings on the table for the project.
Derin, who came to Montreal to co-write a movie, put that on hold and committed to living with us to capture our adventures.
And I gave up four years of working in tech, to fully teach myself how to edit and make videos.
Our parents were more furious than we ever thought they could be.
Our old friends called us lunatics, and a lot of people we respected weren't sold on our plans either.
We took all the feedback and criticism into consideration,
but there was nothing that would stop us continuing our journey
together.
With only three thousand subscribers on our channel at the time, we knew how crazy it all looked.
But believe me, none of us had a single doubt that this was going to work out.
We hope that by telling our story,
we can inspire you to never doubt that you are good enough, and capable of achieving
whatever you set your mind to, as long as you work hard for it.
See you on Sunday for the fifth and final episode of the Yes Theory Origin Series.
